Ken on "continuous speciation":

>The continuous speciation idea is interesting.  People have
>speculated on doing something like that for a long time actually,
>but I don't know of anyone who actually did it before.  It would be
>an interesting study in its own right to see if doing that improves
>the algorithm.  One thing it makes me wonder about is that when you
>have discrete species you can set a target # of species and
>use "dynamic thresholding" to hold that number stable.  Since you
>don't have an actual # in your implementation, you can't set a
>target in the same way.  This brings up what the benefit of setting
>targets is.  One benefit is that it allows you to make sure you
>don't get explosions in the # of species, which would lead to a lack
>of diversity within each species.  In other words, the whole
>population could end up separated from each other.

I've no idea whether Ashot's ideas are exactly the same as mine, but I 
would say that is only a problem when you have non-continuous 
species.  With continuous species you can have N species of 1 and the only 
down-side is that it will be harder to find a partner for sexual 
reproduction (much like any inner-city in that regard :).  If we think 
about what a population like that means, it is indicating that we are in a 
wide area of search-space with very little in the way of fitness 
changes.  That's why no individual stands out enough to be awarded a larger 
proportion of the population.  But in that case it is good to spread the 
population as widely as possible to try and find way off the planes and 
into the mountains.  When an individual finds the foothills, it will get a 
larger proportion of the population, but the speciation mechanism will then 
come into play to stop it immediately taking over the whole thing.

>   Another nice
>thing is it allows several themes to totally diverge from each other
>over long periods of time.  In your scheme, it seems possible that
>because there is no particular guard in place keeping any two
>individuals from mating, over time you might get more uniformity and
>convergence.  Not sure about this though, of course it depends on
>your parameters...but I wonder how things compare.

I think he does have a partial guard, in that he selects mating pairs with 
a probability inversely based on their distance.  But he may also be 
protected by a more natural mechanism, in that when the parents become too 
disparate, they will become "infertile" with one another and although the 
system may try to breed them, their offspring will all be of lower fitness 
than themselves.

In genetic theory this is one possible first-step in the creation of 
natural species.  e.g. where we get two sub-species which produce less-fit 
offspring when cross-bred then when in-bred.  This introduces a selection 
factor to evolve a preference not to mate with the other sub-population, 
which then closes a feed-back loop to drive the two apart.

A contradictory theory, observed in human "attractiveness" studies, 
suggests that there is a best degree of diversity to breed with.  When you 
see a member of the opposite sex who has a different genetic background and 
who seems very sexy in an exotic way, the theory is that person is just 
different enough that your sub-conscious tags them as a really promising 
mate.  The idea is that people who are too similar don't bring your 
offspring any novel factors, and will even lead to more homozygous 
deleterious recessives.  But people who are too different, will have 
(presumably minor) "competing conventions" problems and thus cannot so 
usefully "merge their genetic and cultural differences" with your own.  The 
Borg never mentioned that part, did they :)

Ian
